title: Question 13
prompt: <u>The server at the restaurant spilled spaghetti sauce all over the woman's dress.  The woman complained to the manager.  </u>
description: Read the underlined sentences.  Then choose the sentence that best combines those sentences into one.
feedback:
The best combination of the two sentences uses the word “because” to express the relationship between the two sentences. The dependent, or subordinate, clause “because the server spilled spaghetti sauce all over her dress” is at the end of the sentence, so no comma is needed.

The choice “The server at the restaurant spilled spaghetti sauce all over the woman's dress, she complained to the manager” is a comma splice. Two sentences cannot be joined by only a comma.

The choice “The server at the restaurant spilled spaghetti sauce all over the woman's dress because, she complained, to the manager” is incorrect. It doesn’t express the most appropriate cause-and-effect relationship, since it makes more sense that the woman complained because the server spilled spaghetti sauce. It also has unneeded commas after “because” and “complained.”

The choice “The woman complained to the manager during the server at the restaurant spilling spaghetti sauce all over her dress” doesn’t make the correct logical relationship between the sentences. These sentences describe cause and effect. The word “during” shows a relationship where two things are happening at the same time.
